Ionic bonds are formed when two atoms that have a high electronegativity difference (usually 1.5+) bond together. For example, NaCl (table salt). Chlorine (Cl) has an electronegativity of 3.0 whereas Sodium (Na) has an electronegativity of 0.9. When these two elements are brought together under the right conditions (temperature, pressure, etc), each atom of sodium will donate its electron to the chlorine atom so that they can both reach a more stable configuration (8 or 0 electrons in their valence shell).   Covalent bonding is another kind of bonding in atoms. Atoms that have a smaller electronegativity difference (<1.5) form covalent bonds where instead of donating and receiving electrons, atoms share the electrons. E.g., H20 (water) where 1 atom of oxygen forms a covalent bond with each of the 2 hydrogen atoms. Polar covalent bonds are when the difference in electronegativity is greater (between 0.5 and 1.5), resulting in a slight positive charge on the less electronegative atom (in this case hydrogen) and a slight negative charge on the more electronegative atom (oxygen in this case of water).   Hope this helps!

A summary!  Video One: Carbon  Carbon has 6 neutrons, 6 protons and 6 electrons.  Octet Rule – atoms need 8 electrons in outermost shell to be stable.  Carbon needs 4 electrons to fill its outer shell – can therefore create four bonds.  Halogens are elements that only need one electron to fulfil their octet.  Alkali metals only have one electron in their octet.  Covalent bonding: atoms share electrons with each other to become stable.  Ionic bonding: atoms donate/accept electrons permanently to become stable – they become ions (i.e. positively or negatively charged atoms). Atoms prefer to remain neutral but will become an ion if it means satisfying their outer shells.  Polar charges are when there’s a positive and negative pole driven by the sharing of electrons.  Hydrogen bonding: a relatively weak bond between molecules (e.g. H2O molecules) due to the polar charges, where the positive and negative poles of each molecule are attracted to one another.  Lewis Dot Structures show how molecules are bonded together.

If Carbon has 6 electrons, wouldn't it need 2 more electrons to make 8 electrons (octet rule), or 2 less electrons to have 4x shared  and complete it's outer shell? How does carbon complete it's outer shell with 4 electrons?

@360revolucion8  Carbon has 6 electrons. 2 on the innermost shell, 4 on the outermost shell. On the outermost shell, according to the octet rule, 8 electrons are needed for the atom to be stable. As carbon only has 4 electrons on the outermost shell,  it needs 4 more to complete the octet. Therefore, it can create 4 bonds (ionic, covalent, etc) with other molecules in order gain the full outer shell. Hope this helps! You can also check out the video about 3 minutes in for a nice graphic on it.

I seriously wish you would not make jokes involving  words like 'hussy', 'tramp' and 'sex' or use (and in this case OVER-use) the sexy/cute little drawings in vids that have little to do with it.  I use some of your vids for my middle school classes, and although the word 'sex' is nothing 'bad' in itself, and indeed represents a fundamentally necessary operation when speaking of Biology, one must keep in mind the 'filters' that info passes through with students. By the time they get home, a vid with that word in it so frequently becomes a vid ABOUT it and problems may ensue. If you want to actually consider yourself a teacher, please keep that kind of thing in mind. If you are simply an individual knowledgeable abut a topic and are posting a vid about it, (e.g. a professional biologist or chemist)  that's fine, and enjoyable to adults who understand the context of those words and the joking nature of their relation to the topic.But to "package" these as suitable for younger audiences without being 'clean' is asking for problems. Plus, although I know you will not change this, you speak FAR too quickly in your videos.  I, and several other teachers I know of who use your vids, always slow the playback speed to 75%, It makes you sound slightly inebriated, but it makes your speech  easier to understand. Cheers!
